section.title: Introduction
section.para: The menu on the left side of the classical web interface contains entries which offer a quick way to the information most people need. However you can change the parameters or use other options as well. Some Classic UI modules (CGIs) require an objecttype ("host", "hostgroup", "service", or "servicegroup"), often followed by one or more options. The best way is to take a look at the existing URLs and change them according to your needs.

Below you will find a table showing the parameters and the Classic UI modules they apply to. The names of the Classic UI modules are abbreviated. An explanation along with a hint to the source code can be found here.
Following this table is an explanation of the parameters (work in progress).

section.title: Executing Classic UI modules on the command line
section.para:
Instead of using your browser you may want to run the Classic UI modules on the command line and process the results with other tools. For a first impression change to the folder containing the *.cgi modules (e.g. /usr/local/icinga/sbin), set some environment variables and execute one of the Classic UI modules: $> export REMOTE_USER=icingaadmin # or choose the appropriate user $> export REQUEST_METHOD='GET' # if you enter queries $> export QUERY_STRING='host=all' # see the tables below
$> ./status.cgiDepending on the number of hosts this may return a lot of lines containing HTML code in between which most people will find hard to read so you should add "&csvoutput" or "&jsonoutput" to QUERY_STRING along with other arguments.
Set QUERY_STRING as needed and execute the desired Classic UI module.

If you forgot to set the environment variables you'll receive the following lines: $> ./status.cgi getcgivars(): Unsupported REQUEST_METHOD -> ''
I'm guessing you're trying to execute the CGI from a command line. In order to do that, you need to set the REQUEST_METHOD environment variable to either "GET", "HEAD", or "POST". When using the GET and HEAD methods, arguments can be passed to the CGI by setting the "QUERY_STRING" environment variable. If you're using the POST method, data is read from standard input. Also of note: if you've enabled authentication in the CGIs, you must set the "REMOTE_USER" environment variable to be the name of the user you're "authenticated" as.
You will find some examples here.

section.title: Properties / Statustypes
section.para: You can use status.cgi to show objects with one or more statustype (hoststatustype / servicestatustype) and with certain properties (hostprops / serviceprops). Each statustype / property is identified by a number (shown here and here at the end of this section). Please sum up the appropriate numbers and use the resulting value for each option.
The example shows all non-OK services which are neither in downtime nor acknowledged:
"29" includes PENDING services (not being checked since start up) as well.

note.para: Please note that using properties will only show the objects satisfying ALL conditions whereas the objects are shown when satifying ONE of the statustypes.

section.title: Parameter Details
section.para: Further information regarding the several parameters is given below. For a detailed understanding please have a look at the source code.

row.entry: The command will affects host and its services
Reset modified attributes and don't set them in the future.
How many archive log files will be searched to determine the initial states
Please keep in mind that processing of the files may take a while
Send notification to all contacts (non-escalated and escalated)
0=doesn't affect child hosts; 1=schedule triggered downtime; 2=schedule non-triggered downtime
1 means request, show confirmation form; 2 means commit directly
May depend on the setting of "lock_author_names" in cgi.cfg
A valid contact as mail recipient
Specify whether or not the report output should be in csv format
This option automatically sets "noheader". Added to nearly all CGIs (see note [2])
1=recent alerts; 2=alert totals; 3=top alerts; 4=hostgroup alert totals; 5=host alert totals; 6=service alert totals; 7=servicegroup alert totals
Omit some HTML code and SSI header/footer
End time of the fixed downtime
Whether or not the downtime will be fixed
The service check will be forced
Send notification regardless of restrictions (timeperiods or else)
Which objects should be graphed in what state
A boolean OR of: 1=Host up; 2=Host down; 4=Host unreachable; 8=Service OK; 16=Service Warning; 32=Service Unknown; 64=Service Critical
Select all hosts or a specific host whose services should be displayed
special characters in the name have to be urlencoded (i.e. "%20" instead of a blank)
Select all hostgroups or one specific hostgroup whose hosts and services should be displayed
special characters in the name have to be urlencoded (i.e. "%20" instead of a blank)
Select the hosts (including the services) matching the given bit pattern. Note that the hosts have to match ALL conditions specified
A boolean OR of the states specified in include/cgiutils.c [1] (HOST AND SERVICE FILTER PROPERTIES)
The state the hosts should be in
A boolean OR of the states: 1=DOWN; 2=UNREACHABLE; 4=UP
The state the host should be in
A boolean OR of the states: 1=Pending; 2=Up; 4=Down; 8=Unreachable
Duration of the flexible downtime in full hours (see minutes)
Only valid if defining a flexible downtime
Search for exact match of specified string (for regex search see search_string)
Specify whether or not the report output should be in json format
This option automatically sets "noheader". Added to nearly all CGIs (see note [2])
Number of items to display per page
Used for paging-ability [5]. The summary.cgi doesn't have pagination, default=25.
Duration of the flexible downtime (see hours)
Omit global status information and only show status details
Default: show most recent entries first; see note [6]
Default: show most recent entries first; see note [5]
The string sent as the performance data
The comment will be persistent if this option is set
The string sent as the plugin output
The length is limited by the value of MAX_INPUT_LENGTH (set during compile time)
Specify the state the plugin should have
The command will be propagated to child hosts
Specify a timeperiod which is used for the availability report
Use the short name from the timeperiod definition
Delay command scheduling by n minutes
Find object (host, service, etc) with given string using regular expressions
Send a notification for the acknowledgement
[5] cmd.cgi requires 0|1 vars, if not set, default is 1. View Bug #2926 for additional information.
Select all services or a specific service which should be displayed
Special characters in the name have to be urlencoded (i.e. "%20" instead of a blank)
Select only services matching the given pattern
The pattern is case sensitive. Regular expressions seemed to work up to &name-icinga; 1.6; see search_string
Select all servicegroup or one specific servicegroup whose hosts and services should be displayed
Special characters in the name have to be urlencoded (i.e. "%20" instead of a blank)
Select the services matching the given bit pattern. Note that the services have to match ALL conditions specified
A boolean OR of the states specified in include/cgiutils.c [1] (HOST AND SERVICE FILTER PROPERTIES)
State the services should be in
A boolean OR of the states: 8=Warning; 16=Unknown; 32=Critical; 64=OK
State the services should be in
A boolean OR of the states: 1=Pending; 2=OK, 4=Warning; 8=Unknown; 16=Critical
Importance of services in relation to hosts
Services are 1/n important as hosts. Default: n=4
Specify the column to sort on
Specify the sort order on the column specified by "sortoption=<n>"
1=recent alerts; 2=recent host alerts; 3=recent service alerts; 4=top host alert producers; 5=top service alert producers
Format "MM-DD-YYYY HH:MI" (may depend on your local settings, but unsure about that)
[5] cmd.cgi requires 0|1 vars, if not set, default is 1. View Bug #2926 for additional information.
Specify the information to be shown
only applies to objecttypes "hostgroups" and "servicegroups";hostdetail=host status details; detail=service status details; summary=status summary; grid=status grid;
Start point of a custom timeperiod
End point of a custom timeperiod
Timeperiod which should be used for the availability report
today; yesterday; thisweek; lastweek; thismonth; lastmonth; thisquarter; lastquarter; thisyear; lastyear; last24hours; last7days; last31days; custom
The downtime will be triggered by downtime id <n>
Data is shown up to ts_end (unix timestamp)
Data is shown starting at ts_start (unix timestamp)
hosts; hostgroups; services; servicegroups; contacts; contactgroups; timeperiods; commands; hostescalations; serviceescalations; hostdependencies; servicedependencies

note.para: Starting with 1.8 the 'scroll' parameter was added to status.cgi to save and restore the current scroll position. This is minor, as only used as internal variable when using refresh_type=javascript in cgi.cfg

section.para: [1] Logical OR means that the numbers are added and only the objects will be displayed satisfying ALL conditions (properties).

[3] avail, log, notif, out, status, sum: all views/reports support jsonoutput; config: all types except command expansion; ext: all views except hostgroup/servicegroup info (always without performance data); tac: data output in json format. More details in the &name-icinga; wiki.

section.title: Abbreviations, Classic UI modules, Links
section.para: Abbreviations used in the first table, relations to Classic UI module and menu items, and links to the source code in <icinga-core>/cgis.

row.entry: Comments, Downtime, Process Info, Performance Info, Schedulung Info
Hostgroup Overview, Servicegroup Overview, Host Problems, Service Problems

section.title: Host and Service Filter Properties

para.programlisting:
/*************************** SERVICE STATES ***************************/ #define SERVICE_PENDING 1 #define SERVICE_OK 2 #define SERVICE_WARNING 4 #define SERVICE_UNKNOWN 8 #define SERVICE_CRITICAL 16
/**************************** HOST STATES ****************************/ #define HOST_PENDING 1 #define HOST_UP 2 #define HOST_DOWN 4 #define HOST_UNREACHABLE 8

/***************************** COMMANDS *********************************/
